content.description: This climbs the easy left arete of the Turk Face.  The crux move is down low and involves a facey slab move up a steeper section to a good stance.   The climbing above the stance, though mostly friction, is much easier and follows along the arete up the gentle slab.
content.location:
It is the leftmost route of the Turk Face.  The current start is from the left most side of the horizontal crack that runs across the bottom of the face.   

  Walk off left or right.

content.description: This climbs the right arete and face. From the horizontal, make a series of increasingly tenuous moves using the arete when possible. The climb eases near the top where the arete become more positive.This is more bouldery than Grinch Breath. I am not sure if it’s harder.
content.protection: 2 bolts at the top.  They are on the face of the short second tier.
content.location: It ascends the right arete of the left face.

content.description:
This is a fun, pure friction climb at a moderate grade.   

  It starts just right of the crescent-shaped flake.  Smear upwards toward the belay tree.   Trending left into Turkish Delight will make it easier, and trending left into Grinch Breath will make it harder (so try to stay in the middle!).  The first half is the crux, after that the angle eases off.
content.location: Right of center there is an obvious, crescent-shaped flake above the horizontal.  Start just right of the flake (use it if you must).  Walk of left or right.

content.description:
This is a marvelously thin line and a real celebration of the synergy between textured rock and sticky rubber.   The only true hand hold is at the top.  It is also still a bit dirty and could use a little love.   

  This climbs the steep section just right of Pale Blue Eyes and just left of an obvious uncleaned mossy area. Smear up the steep section aiming for an small hand hold near the top. About two thirds of the way up, you will meet slight, right-facing flake: the crux is below this after which the climbing eases but not considerably. Once you reach the hand hold, head left to the belay tree.   

  This is maybe three stars for those who like smearing on nasty Cape Ann granite.
content.location: This climbs the steep section just right of Pale Blue Eyes and just left of an obvious uncleaned mossy area. Smear up the steep section aiming for an small hand hold near the top. About two thirds of the way up, you will pass a slight, right-facing flake: the crux is below this after which the climbing eases but not considerably. A few more moves gets you to a lichen section where you will find the finishing the hand hold, then head left to the belay tree.

content.description:
This is the larger, left hand slab at the Pet Slabs.  It contains several fun friction routes.  The left side is very moderate and lower angle, but the right side is quite steep.   Having been protected under a layer of thick moss, the rock here is mostly lichen-free and amazingly grippy leading to excellent friction, which is good considering the noticeable absence of holds.  Because of the blankness of the rock, actual lines are difficult to follow.  Routes listed are mere suggestions. 

  Most of the routes can be top-roped from a small tree right at the top of the slab.  If it seems this slab is getting use, I'll add anchors.
